title-group.article-title: Verbal fluency in Alzheimer's disease and Aphasia

author-notes.corresp: Professor Eva Maria Arroyo-Anlló, Department of Psychobiology, University of Salamanca, 37007 Salamanca, Spain Email: anlloa@usal.es

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study examined the impact of two neurological diseases on access to semantic knowledge and the status of semantic representations. Patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD) and Aphasia (APH) were compared with control groups using the supermarket fluency task. We measured several aspects: number of category names produced, number of categories sampled to produce the words, the number of words per category sampled, number of exemplars and kinds of errors recorded. Both AD and APH groups produced significantly fewer words on the fluency task than control groups. As compared with the APH and control groups, in the AD group verbal fluency was characterized by a tendency to generate more category names with fewer exemplars within a category. The findings are consistent with the view that a bottom-up disruption in semantic knowledge occurs in AD and a general semantic disruption occurs in Aphasia.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Verbal fluency can be defined as the ability to retrieve items belonging to a specified category within a limited time period. Verbal fluency is typically measured using semantic retrieval (e.g., retrieval of words from the semantic category of ‘fruits’) and letter retrieval (e.g., retrieval of words that begin with the letter ‘R’). Semantic fluency relies more heavily on access to lexical representations of semantic concepts than letter fluency (Baddeley, 1992; Gold & Buckner, 2002).

It is now well known that patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD) exhibit naming deficits attributed to a ‘disorganization of semantic fields’ (Ajuriaguerra & Tissot, 1968) or to a breakdown in the retrieval of semantic knowledge (Patterson & Hodges, 1995; Schwartz, Marin, & Saffran, 1979; Warrington, 1975, 1981). Impaired verbal fluency, which has to do with access to lexical and semantic information, has been documented in AD patients (Butters, Granholm, Salmon, Grant, & Wolfe, 1987; Cerhan et al., 2002; Coen et al., 1996; Diaz, Salilor, Cheung, & Kuslansky, 2004; Flicker, Ferris, Crook, & Bartus, 1987; Hart, Smith, & Swash, 1988; Keilp, Gorlyn, Alexander, Stern, & Prohovnik, 1999; Ober, Dronkers, Koss, Delis, & Friedland, 1986; Rogers & Friedman, 2008; Tierney et al., 2001; Tippet, Gendall, Farah, & Thompson-Schill, 2004; Tröster et al., 1998; Vitali et al., 2005). Studies observed that patients in various other groups of degenerative dementias also performed more poorly on category and letter fluency tasks compared to normal controls (Duff Canning, Leach, Stuss, Ngo, & Black, 2004; Kertesz, Davidson, McCabe, Takagi, & Muñoz, 2003; Marczinski & Kertesz, 2006). Several works have found that AD patients have a tendency to generate more category names (e.g., Fruits) concurrent with a reduced proportion of items (e.g., Banana) within a very broad category such as grocery items (Martin, 1987; Martin & Fedio, 1983). It has been suggested that AD patients remember the names of categories (e.g., ‘clothes’), but lose some of the defining features and specific items (e.g., ‘coat’) semantically associated with these abstract labels. So, it seems that AD patients may show a progressive bottom-up breakdown of the structure of semantic knowledge, which occurs even in the earliest stage of AD.

On the other hand, aphasia is an acquired communication disorder that impairs a person's ability to process language, but does not affect intelligence. Several studies have suggested that aphasia produces a disorganization of semantic fields or, lexico-semantic problems in general (Chapey, Rigrodsky, & Morrison, 1977; Gainotti, Silveri, Villa, & Miceli, 1986; Goodglass, Klein, Carey, & Jones, 1966; Hough, 1993; Lhermitte, Derouesne, & Leccours, 1971; Yamadori & Albert, 1973). The verbal production of aphasic subjects may include words which have remote connections with a target word – phonemic errors, e.g., fable for table, or semantic errors, e.g., table for chair – or no connection whatsoever. There are two fundamental forms of aphasia, linked to defects in the lexico-semantic (Wernicke-type aphasia) and grammatical systems of language (Broca-type aphasia). In letter and category fluency tasks, fluent and non fluent aphasic patients showed fewer responses and fewer correct responses than normal control subjects (Adams & Reich, 1989; Ardila, 2006; Bruyer & Tuyumbu, 1981; Caplan, 2006; Sarno, Postman, Cho, & Norman, 2005). We are not aware of any work having been done to establish the characteristics of destruction of semantic knowledge in aphasia using fluency tasks or comparing aphasic and Alzheimer patients concerning the profile of the destruction of the semantic structure.

In light of several studies suggesting that category tasks rely heavily on access to lexical representations of semantic concepts (Caramazza & Berndt, 1978; Lhermitte et al., 1971; Marczinski & Kertesz, 2006; Pompeia, Rusted, & Curran, 2002; Van der Linden, 1989), more production of semantic categories than items from categories reflects a ‘bottom-up’ disruption of semantic knowledge and more production of items than categories reflects a ‘top-down’ disruption of semantic knowledge.

The goal of the present study was to analyse the kinds of responses given on a supermarket task to see whether we would find different profiles of impaired semantic structure in AD and aphasic patients. We hypothesized that AD patients would show a ‘bottom-up’ disturbance of semantic structure, whereas aphasic patients would show a ‘top-down’ disturbance of semantic structure.

sec.title: Subjects
sec.p: Seventy individuals were evaluated in this study: 18 aphasic patients, 17 patients with AD and 35 normal subjects. All patients came from the Department of Neurology at Jean Bernard Hospital in Poitiers, a French University Hospital.

The patients with AD had a history of progressive decline in intellectual function without focal motor or sensory features. The mean duration of the disease was 3.4 years. To exclude other possible causes of dementia, appropriate laboratory tests were performed and these gave normal results. No findings incompatible with the diagnosis of AD were found in the electroencephalogram, electrocardiogram or chest X-ray in any of the patients. Brain CT scan revealed mild cortical and central atrophy, but no other pathology. All Alzheimer patients (8 women and 9 men) fulfilled the diagnostic criteria of the ‘NINCDS - ADRDA Work Group’ (McKhann et al., 1984) and of the DSM III – R (1987). All had a score of less than 5 on the Hachinski Ischemic Scale (Hachinski, Iliff, & Zilhka, 1975). AD patients had mild AD, according to the Clinical Dementia Rating System (Hughes, Berg, Danziger, Coben, & Martin, 1982) and Rapid Evaluation of Cognitive Function (ERCF, Gil et al., 1986). The AD group had an ERCF mean score (± SD) of 36.19 (± 7.71) and a mean age (± SD) of 76.11 (± 4.83) years. AD patients had a mean educational level (± SD) of 4.05 (± 1.63), using the classification of Barbizet and Duizabo (1985): illiterate (educational level 1 -EL 1-), to read, to write and to count (EL 2), 6 years of education (EL 3), 9 years of education (EL 4), 11 or 12 years of education (EL 5), 13 years of education (EL 6) and more than 13 years of education (EL 7).

According to the literature, defects in the lexico-semantic system are more characteristic of fluent aphasia than non-fluent aphasia (Ardila, 2006; Goodglass & Kaplan, 1983). Thus, we elected to study semantic fluency performance in fluent aphasia patients. Toward the goal of selecting fluent aphasic patients, a speech-language pathologist determined the aphasia diagnosis for 31 patients following traditional guidelines (Goodglass & Kaplan, 1983). Diagnoses were made on the basis of conversational interaction and analysis of linguistic deficits observed on tests of language performance, using the Montreal-Toulouse protocol (Nespoulous et al., 1986). This language protocol assesses oral and written expression as well as oral and written comprehension in French-speaking patients, with scores ranging from 0 to 86. Of the 31 aphasic patients assessed, 18 had fluent aphasia. The remaining thirteen were excluded from the present analysis because of incomplete data sets or they did not respond at all in fluency task. According to the Montreal-Toulouse protocol and the Aphasia Severity Scale of the Boston Diagnostic Aphasia Examination (BDAE; Goodglass & Kaplan, 1983) which described 6 degrees of language deficit (0-5), the aphasic group had mild language problems. Aphasic patients (APH) had a mean Montreal-Toulouse protocol (± SD) of 76 (± 4.9) and a mean rating of 4.1 (±1.00) on the Aphasia Severity Scale. The aetiology of the aphasia patients’ illness was ischemic stroke in the left sylvian territory. A MRI neuro-image of an aphasic patient is presented in Figure 1. Figure 1.
MRI image of an aphasic patient shows one ischemic stroke in left posterior sylvian territory.

The mean duration since the stroke was 3.1 years. The APH group had a mean age (± SD) of 50.58 (± 14.44) years and a mean educational level (± SD) of 3.05 (± 1.42), using the classification of Barbizet and Duizabo (1985).

The 35 control individuals were hospital visitors or employees with no history of disease affecting the brain and heart, drug abuse or thyroid dysfunction. They were divided into two groups matched to patients’ groups, according to age, gender and educational level. The demographic characteristics of these groups are presented in Table 1. Table 1.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Verbal fluency was evaluated by the supermarket task from the MDRS: Mattis Dementia Rating Scale (Mattis, 1976). The supermarket fluency task explores semantic knowledge, and was used in studies such as those by Martin and Fedio (1983) and Tröster et al. (1989). Subjects were allotted 60 seconds to name different items that can be found in a supermarket. Only the first 20 responses made by a subject were recorded, the maximum score being 20. Prior to data tabulation, this fluency task was reviewed to determine the categories (e.g., meat, vegetables, drinks, etc.) from which subjects drew the items they had named. The review revealed that items could be placed in a maximum of 12 categories, two more than Tröster et al. (1989): Meats, Grains, Dairy, Drinks, Fruit, Vegetables, Dessert and snacks, Edible household goods, Non-edible household goods, Personal items, Electrical appliances and Recreation. A ‘category’ can be defined as a response (e.g., ‘fruit’) which would leave a hypothetical shopper a choice with respect to the particular item someone would buy. An ‘exemplar’ can be defined as a response (e.g., ‘apples’) which would leave a hypothetical shopper with no choice regarding the item someone would buy. For example, a subject producing the words ‘meat, grapes, bread and broccoli’ would have sampled four categories (meats, fruit, grains and vegetables) to produce three correct exemplars and one word (‘meat’) is also a category label.

For each subject, the following data were tabulated:
The number of words per category sampled (obtained by dividing the total number of correct different words by the number of categories sampled): the ratio of correct words produced to number of categories sampled.
The number of category names produced (number of words representing category labels).
The ratio of the number of category labels produced relative to total output (including errors) was obtained by dividing the number of category labels produced by total output. Obviously, the greater this ratio, the greater the dominance of category labels over specific exemplars. Conversely, the smaller the ratio, the greater the tendency to produce specific exemplars rather than category labels.
The number of specific exemplars (without errors).
The number of perseverations and intrusions made and errors ratios. Perseveration being defined as repeated words and intrusion as words representing items unobtainable in a supermarket.

The order of administration of the supermarket task and cognitive tests was randomized among the participants to minimize interference. Reponses were tape-recorded for the fluency task. Data were analysed using the SPSS software. Lilliefords' method (Dallal & Wilkinson, 1986) was used to determine whether the data were normally distributed by quantifying the discrepancy between the distributions of experimental data from an ideal Gaussian distribution. Because the results were not normally distributed, we used non-parametric statistics to assess differences in means for each variable (Mann Whitney (MW): z score and Wilcoxon tests). All hypotheses were tested at α = .05.

sec.title: Demographic characteristics
sec.p: The means and standard deviations of various demographic characteristics of the controls, the AD patients and the APH patients are shown in Table 1. There was no significant difference in gender or educational level distributions among the groups. In addition, patient groups did not differ significantly in the duration of their illness. There was a significant difference in the age distribution of all the groups; the AD patients were older than the APH patients, as shown in Table 1. For the general cognitive tests, the patient groups’ scores were significantly lower than those of the relevant control groups. But there was no significant difference in the ERCF or the WAIS Similarities and Digit Symbol Coding subtests scores of the patient groups. However, there was a significant difference in the Vocabulary score of the patient groups; the APH group scored the lowest, as shown in Table 1. For the non-cognitive test, there was no significant difference among any of the groups according to the Zerssen Rating Scale.

sec.title: Supermarket fluency task performances
sec.p: a) Preliminary analyses. The total number of correct words produced and the total output (including errors) of each patient group were markedly low in comparison to that of the relevant control group: APH Controls vs. APH (mean ± standard deviations: 18.55 ± 2.43 vs. 8.55 ± 4.76; MW: z = 4.79; p < .01 and 19.05 ± 1.92 vs. 8.94 ± 4.92; MW: z = 4.65; p < .01, respectively) and AD Controls vs. AD (17.05 ± 3.57 vs. 8.52 ± 3.6; MW: z = 4.41; p < .001 and 17.58 ± 3.46 vs. 8.94 ± 3.57; MW: z = 4.42; p < .01, respectively). Although the age difference of the two control groups was statistically significant, the total number of correct words and the total output of each one were not significant (MW: z = 1.28; p = .20 and MW: z = 1.28; p = .20, respectively), even corrected for age (p > .05). Comparisons between patient groups indicated that number of correct different words in the AD group was similar to that of the APH group (MW: z = 0.20; p = .841), with a similar total output (MW: z = 0.26; p = .803). Besides, the APH group sampled fewer categories in generating their responses than did the control group (mean ± standard deviations: 4.44 ± 2.17 vs. 7.61 ± 2.03; MW: z = 3.59; p < .01). The AD group sampled fewer categories in generating their responses than did the control group (4.94 ± 1.67 vs. 7 ± 1.8; MW: z = 2.94; p < .01). However the AD group did not differ significantly from the APH group in terms of the number of categories sampled (MW: z = 0.79; p = .43).

b) Principal analyses. The means and standard deviations of the experimental data produced by each of groups are presented in Table 2. The results of the tabulated data are the following:
The number of words per category sampled. The control group for the APH patients did not differ significantly from the AD control group (MW: z = 0.04; p = .96). Each of the patient groups produced fewer words per category sampled than did their respective controls: the APH control group vs. the APH group (MW: z = 2.56; p < .01); the AD control group vs. the AD group (MW: z = 2.92; p < .01). However, the APH group did not differ significantly from the AD group (MW: z = 1.07; p = .28).
The number of words representing category labels, and thus the number of category names produced. The two control groups produced a similar absolute number of category names (MW: z = 0.31; p = .757). The APH group gave significantly fewer category names than the control group (MW: z = 2.48; p < .01). The AD group gave fewer category names than the control group, although the difference did not reach significance (MW: z = 1.68; p = .09). The AD group tended to give more category names than the APH group, although the difference did not reach significance (MW: z = 1.32; p = .18).
The ratio of the number of category labels produced relative to total output. The category label ratio was similar for the two control groups (MW: z = 0.04; p = .96). The APH group produced a ratio similar to that of the control group (MW: z = 0.01; p = .992). The AD group tended to produce a relative higher ratio of number of category labels than either the control group or the APH patients, but the difference did not reach significance (MW: z = 1.12; p = .26; MW: z = 1.58; p = .114, respectively). The mean ratio of category labels to total words produced for each of the four subject groups is presented in Figure 2.
The number of specific exemplars (without errors). Owing to these last results, we compared the absolute number of exemplars to the number of category names for each group, using the Wilcoxon non-parametric T test. The two control groups generated significantly more exemplars than names of categories (APH Controls: T = 10; p < .01 and AD Controls: T = 31.5; p < .05). The APH group produced significantly more exemplars than names of categories (T = 16; p < .01). Eighty-five percent of the APH subjects (15 of 18) showed this profile. However, the AD group produced a similar number of exemplars and category names. So, the AD group did not show a significant difference between number of exemplars and number of category names (T = 4.55; p > .05). Seventy-five percent of the AD subjects (13 of 17) produced category and exemplar responses with nearly equal frequency. AD patient's fluency test responses and the scores on each variable for that AD patient are presented in Appendix 1. The number of category names and the number of exemplars for the four subject groups are presented in Figure 3.
Perseverations, intrusions and errors ratios. Control groups did not generate any kind of error. Although repetition and intrusion errors were slightly more common in the AD group (0.85 ± 1.34; 0.07 ± 0.26, respectively) compared to the APH group (0.46 ± 0.26; 0.05 ± 0.1, respectively), no statistical analysis was carried out because the absolute number of errors committed was too low. Nevertheless, the AD group tended to generate more repetition errors than the APH group.
Figure 2.
Ratio of category labels relative to output for the four subject groups: AD (Alzheimer's disease group), APH (Aphasic group), AD and APH controls. Figure 3.
Number of category names and Number of exemplars for the four subject groups : AD (Alzheimer's disease group), APH (Aphasic group), AD and APH controls. Table 2.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results provide support for the notion that AD patients tend to produce a ‘bottom-up’ breakdown in the structure of semantic memory, whereas aphasic patients tend to give a more general disturbance of semantic structure. In general, AD and AH groups tend to generate fewer correct words on the supermarket task than the normal control subjects.

All the AD patients were characterized by the similar performance in fluency task. So, the AD patients retrieved fewer words per category sampled and produced more category labels (relative to category exemplars), than normal controls did. The AD patients evidenced not only a marked reduction in the number of exemplars per category sampled but also an increased propensity to generate category labels. As several studies have noted (Martin, 1987; Martin & Fedio, 1983; Marczinski & Kertesz, 2006; Troster et al., 1989), these qualitative features of the AD patients’ overall deficits in verbal fluency support the proposal that a bottom-up deterioration of the hierarchical structure of semantic knowledge has occurred. So, AD patients show a specific pattern of disruption in the hierarchical structure of semantic knowledge, because the verbal representation of an object is stored with its most general attributes and name at the top of the hierarchy and with its specific features and exemplars at the bottom. While demented patients retain category labels, they generate few exemplars of the categories in fluency task. The present study also indicates that these changes in semantic memory are present in the early stages of AD, because the AD patients in question had a mild dementia. Most of AD patients were characterized by the same qualitative features: i.e., few examples per category sampled and a tendency to an ‘over-representation’ of category labels.

Other evidence that AD patients show the proposed bottom-up breakdown of semantic memory was presented by Bayles and Tomoeda (1983). They found that AD patients made predominantly semantic errors on a test of confrontation naming. AD patients had the propensity to substitute superodinates for target words (e.g., ‘animal’ for ‘tiger’). Given the low number of errors in our study, we could not analyze the error data in this way. Nevertheless, category-exemplar priming or semantic priming using super-ordinate word pairs (e.g., bird-robin) is known to be strongly conceptual and consistently impaired in studies of clinical AD (Fleischman & Gabrieli, 1998; Fleischman et al., 2005; Laisney, Giffard, & Eustache, 2004; Perri et al., 2003; Salmon, Shimamura, Butters, & Smith, 1988; Smith, Butters, White, Lyon, & Granholm, 1988). A recent study of Rogers and Freedman (2008) used an implicit lexical-decision priming task to examine the integrity of the underlying semantic network in AD and semantic dementia patients matched for degree of impairment on explicit semantic memory tasks. The results suggested that AD patients’ impairment on explicit semantic tests is a product of a partially degraded semantic network in combination with a deficient explicit retrieval. It could be interesting to study semantic priming effects with our AD group in a future work in order to verify that hypothesis.

Furthermore, the category fluency task is more dependent upon semantic knowledge compared to the letter fluency task. Several studies have reported that AD patients are more impaired on category than on letter fluency tasks (Baddeley, 1992; Butters et al., 1987; Diaz et al., 2004; Duff Canning et al., 2004; Gold & Buckner, 2002; Tippet et al., 2004; Marczinski & Kertesz, 2006; Vitali et al., 2005). Dissociations on such fluency tasks may be indicative of a subtle structural deterioration in semantic memory. We did not study letter fluency, but it will be interesting for future studies to verify this hypothesis.

The results could not easily be explained by a general retrieval deficit, because there is no reason to expect specific exemplars and general categories to be differentially affected. It is suggested that other impairments involving the very structure of semantic knowledge must also be influencing patients’ performances on fluency tests. But we consider that a bottom-up breakdown could be associated with a general retrieval deficit because of poor performances in the number of exemplars and category names.

In addition, the APH group shows impairment to lexical access reflected in a reduction of verbal fluency, but the profile of results is different from that of the AD patients. In the supermarket task, the APH patients generated a similar number of exemplars and words per category sampled than the AD patients. However, the APH patients generated fewer categories sampled than the AD patients. Furthermore, the APH and control groups produced more exemplars than category names. The APH patients showed an over-representation of exemplars and thus a homogenous disruption of semantic knowledge. The APH patients therefore did not show a ‘bottom-up’ breakdown, because they did not generate category names predominantly.

These findings cannot be accounted for by differences in disease duration. The patient groups were matched for disease severity and there were no differences between the groups in the duration of illness, educational level or gender distribution. Significant age differences between the patient groups were relatively consistent with the disease processes involved, APH patients being somewhat younger than the AD patients. The results are not easily explainable by a difference of general cognitive state, because we found no significant differences between the patient groups according to the rapid evaluation of cognition function (Gil et al., 1986), WAIS-R Similarities and Digit Symbol Coding subtests of the Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale Revised (Wechsler, 1989). Nevertheless, the APH group had a significantly poorer score in the Vocabulary subtest (WAIS-R; (Wechsler, 1989) than the AD group. The vocabulary subtest consists of defining a list of words and it measures expressive semantic knowledge. The responses of the AD patients generally consisted of defining words using the semantic category of the words (e.g., chair: ‘furniture’) and the APH patients generally defined words using specific features of words (e.g., chair: ‘to sit down with legs’). This study included a non-cognitive measure of subjects, the Zerssen Rating Scale, but the results cannot be explained by mood, because none of the subjects showed any deficit.

In summary, the present study suggests that the breakdown of semantic knowledge in AD follows a bottom-up pattern, whereas the deterioration seen in APH patients could involve homogenous disruption of semantic knowledge. Future studies may fruitfully explore patterns of semantic memory deficits in other patient groups with language problems on verbal fluency tasks. Finally, the current study has expanded on previous reports and illustrated that verbal fluency tasks can provide a wealth of information regarding the status of verbal representations.

bio.p: M. Lorber studied speech therapy at the University of Tours (France) and completed his clinical practice in the Neuropsychological Unit, University Hospital of Poitiers (France).

François Rigaleau studied Psychology at the University of Poitiers (France) and he then became a postdoctoral student of Prof. Nespoulus and Prof. Gil. He completed his clinical practice in the Neuropsychological Unit, University Hospital of Poitiers (France). In 2004, he joined the Department of Language Sciences and Cognition at the University of Poitiers (France) as Professor, where he is currently tenured professor and investigator.

Roger Gil is a Professor of Neurology at the Faculty of Medicine and Pharmacy in the Univesity of Poitiers (France) and he is head of the Unit for Neuropsychology and Language Rehabilitation at the University Hospital of Poitiers.

Eva Maria Arroyo-Anlló is a Professor of Neuropsychology at the Faculty of Psychology in the University of Salamanca (Spain) and the Faculty of Medicine − Pharmacy in the University of Poitiers (France). She completed his clinical practice and research training in the Neuropsychological Unit, University Hospital of Poitiers (France) and Hôtel-Dieu of Montreal (Canada).
